citeinfo.origin: United States Department of Commerce, United States Census Bureau (creator)
citeinfo.title: CENSUS_BLOCKGROUPS_TIGER2011_IN: Census Block Group Areas for Indiana in 2011 (United States Census Bureau, 1:100,000, Polygon Shapefile)
citeinfo.othercit:
The source data set was downloaded by personnel of the Indiana Geological Survey (IGS) on August 27, 2012, from the following Web page of the U. S. Department of Commerce, U. S. Census Bureau: http://www.census.gov/geo/www/tiger/tgrshp2011/tgrshp2011.html (The data set provided was in an ESRI shapefile format, and was named "tl_2011_18_bg.shp.")
Please visit the following URL to read the technical documentation for the 2011 TIGER/Line shapefiles (downloadable from the following link as an Adobe Acrobat PDF document named "TGRSHP2011_TECHDOC.PDF": http://www.census.gov/geo/www/tiger/tgrshp2011/documentation.html

descript.abstract:
CENSUS_BLOCKGROUPS_TIGER2011_IN.SHP is a polygon shapefile that contains 2011 census block group boundaries for the state of Indiana. Census block groups are not legal boundaries, but are considered stable geographic units used for the presentation of decennial census data.
The following is excerpted from an Adobe Acrobat PDF document named "TGRSHP2011_TECHDOC.PDF (U.S. Census Bureau):
"Block groups are clusters of blocks within the same census tract that have the same first digit of their 4-digit census block number. For example, blocks 3001, 3002, 3003, …., 3999 in census tract 1210.02 belong to Block Group 3. As with block groups delineated for Census 2000, block groups delineated for 5-38 the 2010 Census generally contain between 600 and 3,000 people. Most block groups were delineated by local participants in the Census Bureau's Participant Statistical Areas Program. The Census Bureau delineated block groups only where a local or tribal government declined to participate or where the Census Bureau could not identify a potential local participant.
"A block group usually covers a contiguous area. Each census tract contains at least one block group and block groups are uniquely numbered within census tract. Within the standard census geographic hierarchy, block groups never cross county or census tract boundaries, but may cross the boundaries of county subdivisions, places, urban areas, voting districts, congressional districts, and American Indian, Alaska Native, and Native Hawaiian areas.
"Block groups have a valid range of 0 through 9. Block groups beginning with a 0 generally are in coastal and Great Lakes water and territorial seas. Rather than extending a census tract boundary into the Great Lakes or out to the three-mile territorial sea limit, the Census Bureau delineated some census trac boundaries along the shoreline or just offshore. The Census Bureau assigned a default census tract number of 0 and block group of 0 to the offshore areas not included in regularly numbered census tract areas. Because of updates since 2000, there are 0 block groups that now contain land."
descript.purpose:
To provide a GIS data layer of 2011 census block group boundaries for the state of Indiana. Census block groups are not legal boundaries, but are considered stable geographic units used for the presentation of decennial census data.
The following is excerpted from an Adobe Acrobat PDF document named "TGRSHP2011_TECHDOC.PDF (U.S. Census Bureau):
"Block groups are clusters of blocks within the same census tract that have the same first digit of their 4-digit census block number. For example, blocks 3001, 3002, 3003, …., 3999 in census tract 1210.02 belong to Block Group 3. As with block groups delineated for Census 2000, block groups delineated for 5-38 the 2010 Census generally contain between 600 and 3,000 people. Most block groups were delineated by local participants in the Census Bureau's Participant Statistical Areas Program. The Census Bureau delineated block groups only where a local or tribal government declined to participate or where the Census Bureau could not identify a potential local participant.
"A block group usually covers a contiguous area. Each census tract contains at least one block group and block groups are uniquely numbered within census tract. Within the standard census geographic hierarchy, block groups never cross county or census tract boundaries, but may cross the boundaries of county subdivisions, places, urban areas, voting districts, congressional districts, and American Indian, Alaska Native, and Native Hawaiian areas.
"Block groups have a valid range of 0 through 9. Block groups beginning with a 0 generally are in coastal and Great Lakes water and territorial seas. Rather than extending a census tract boundary into the Great Lakes or out to the three-mile territorial sea limit, the Census Bureau delineated some census trac boundaries along the shoreline or just offshore. The Census Bureau assigned a default census tract number of 0 and block group of 0 to the offshore areas not included in regularly numbered census tract areas. Because of updates since 2000, there are 0 block groups that now contain land."

timeperd.current: Based on information contained in technical document "TGRSHP2011_TECHDOC.PDF" (U.S. Census Bureau)

idinfo.native: ESRI ArcCatalog version 10.1 shapefile format, approximately 19.4 Mb

attracc.attraccr: No formal metadata in the format of the Federal Geographic Data Committee (FGDC) was provided by the U.S. Census Bureau pertaining to the source data for this shapefile. For a more detailed discussion of how the U.S. Census Bureau created these data, please access the technical document Adobe Acrobat file found at the following URL: http://www.census.gov/geo/www/tiger/tgrshp2011/documentation.html

dataqual.logic: This data set was provided by the U. S. Census Bureau and is assumed to be topologically accurate and complete.
dataqual.complete: This data set was provided by the U. S. Census Bureau and is assumed to be complete.

horizpa.horizpar: No information was provided by the U.S. Census Bureau pertaining to the horizontal positional accuracy of the source data.

vertacc.vertaccr: The vertical positional accuracy was not a factor in the production of this data.

citeinfo.origin: United States Department of Commerce, United States Census Bureau (USCB)
citeinfo.title: tl_2011_18_bg.SHP (Indiana Census Block Groups from 2011 TIGER/Line shapefiles)
citeinfo.othercit: Data is from U.S.Census Bureau, 2011 TIGER/Line shapefiles.

srcinfo.typesrc: .ZIP file downloaded from the following URL ( http://www.census.gov/geo/www/tiger/tgrshp2011/tgrshp2011.html ).

srctime.srccurr: Based on metadata provided by USCB for the source shapefile tl_2011_18_bg.SHP.

srcinfo.srccontr: Indiana census block groups from 2011 TIGER/Line shapefiles

procstep.procdesc: IGS personnel downloaded the file named "tl_2011_18_bg.SHP" from the U.S. Census Bureau Web site for 2011 TIGER/Line Shapefiles ( http://www.census.gov/geo/www/tiger/tgrshp2011/tgrshp2011.html ). The shapefile was loaded into ESRI ArcMap 10.1 and examined for completeness, attribute accuracy, and spatial accuracy. The shapefile was then reprojected into the Transverse Mercator projection and UTM Zone 16, NAD 1983 coordinate system. The fields named "INTPTLAT" and "INTPTLON" were deleted from the attribute table. IGS Personnel then renamed then saved the shapefile as CENSUS_BLOCKGROUPS_TIGER2011_IN.SHP. It should be noted that attribute data from the 2010 U.S. Census Data SF1 tables have not been added to the attribute data.

This metadata file was pre-parsed and parsed using CNS (Chew and Spit, v. 2.6.1) and MP (Metadata Parser, v. 2.7.1) software written by Peter N. Schweitzer (U.S. Geological Survey). The errors generated by MP were all addressed and corrected, except that no values were assigned to "Abscissa_Resolution" and "Ordinate_Resolution."

attr.attrdef: Census Block Group Code of 2010 Census
attr.attrdefs: U.S. Census Bureau, 2010 Census, Technical Documentation

attr.attrdef: 2010 Census Block Group Identifier, a concatenation of State FIPS code, County FIPS Code, Census Tract Code, and Census Block Group Code
attr.attrdefs: U.S. Census Bureau, 2010 Census, Technical Documentation

attr.attrdef: 2010 Census Block Group Name, this is the census tract code converted to an integer or integer plus two-digit decimal if the last two characters of the code are not both zeros
attr.attrdefs: U.S. Census Bureau, 2010 Census, Technical Documentation

attr.attrdef: Census translated legal/statistical area description and the Block Group name

distinfo.distliab:
CREDIT
It is requested that the U. S. Department of Commerce, U. S. Census Bureau and the Indiana Geological Survey be cited in any products generated from these data. The following source citation should be included: [CENSUS_BLOCKGROUPS_TIGER2011_IN: Census Block Group Areas for Indiana in 2011 (United States Census Bureau, 1:100,000, Polygon Shapefile)].
WARRANTY
Indiana University, Indiana Geological Survey warrants that the media on which this product is stored will be free from defect in materials and workmanship for ninety (90) days from the date of acquisition. If such a defect is found, return the media to Publication Sales, Indiana Geological Survey, 611 North Walnut Grove, Bloomington, Indiana 47405, and it will be replaced free of charge.
LIMITATION OF WARRANTIES AND LIABILITY
Except for the expressed warranty above, the product is provided "AS IS", without any other warranties or conditions, expressed or implied, including, but not limited to, warranties for product quality, or suitability to a particular purpose or use. The risk or liability resulting from the use of this product is assumed by the user. Indiana University, Indiana Geological Survey shares no liability with product users indirect, incidental, special, or consequential damages whatsoever, including, but not limited to, loss of revenue or profit, lost or damaged data or other commercial or economic loss. Indiana University, Indiana Geological Survey is not responsible for claims by a third party. The maximum aggregate liability to the original purchaser shall not exceed the amount paid by you for the product.

metainfo.metuc: This metadata file is intended to accompany the data set identified and received from the IGS. It should not to be altered or summarized. IGS does not support secondary distribution. If this data set was received from anyone besides the IGS, this metadata file and the data set it describes may lack integrity.
